\/D:\/repos\/stride-translations\/pt-BR\: When you enable this post effect, the scene is reflected in glossy materials.
When you enable this post effect, the scene is reflected in glossy materials.
You can enable and customize local reflections in the graphics compositor on the <g1>post effects</g1> properties.
You can enable and customize local reflections in the graphics compositor on the <g1>post effects</g1> properties.
Xenko 2.1 includes a <g1>clear-coat material</g1> template that uses physically-based rendering to simulate vehicle paint.
Xenko 2.1 includes a <g1>clear-coat material</g1> template that uses physically-based rendering to simulate vehicle paint.
Clear-coat shading has several advantages over creating the effect manually with material layers:
Clear-coat shading has several advantages over creating the effect manually with material layers:
layers are blended based on distance
layers are blended based on distance
You can add a predefined <g1>clear coat</g1> material from the <g2>Asset view</g2> under <g3>Add asset > Material</g3>.
You can add a predefined <g1>clear coat</g1> material from the <g2>Asset view</g2> under <g3>Add asset > Material</g3>.
You can now render thin glass materials such as windshields.
You can now render thin glass materials such as windshields.
The diffuse color controls the tint of the glass and how much light is blocked (darker colors block more light).
The diffuse color controls the tint of the glass and how much light is blocked (darker colors block more light).
You can add a predefined <g1>Glass</g1> material from the <g2>Asset view</g2> under <g3>Add asset > Material</g3>.
You can add a predefined <g1>Glass</g1> material from the <g2>Asset view</g2> under <g3>Add asset > Material</g3>.
You can now use <g1>light shafts</g1> with any kind of light that casts shadows (ie point lights, directional lights, or spot lights).
You can now use <g1>light shafts</g1> with any kind of light that casts shadows (ie point lights, directional lights, or spot lights).
You can also use them with multiple shadow cascades.
You can also use them with multiple shadow cascades.
Additionally, Game Studio now displays light shaft bounding volumes in the scene editor, so you can easily see the areas where light shafts are created.
Additionally, Game Studio now displays light shaft bounding volumes in the scene editor, so you can easily see the areas where light shafts are created.
To show or hide navigation light shaft bounding volumes, in the <g1>scene editor toolbar</g1>, open the <g2>gizmo options</g2> menu and use the <g3>Light shaft bounding volumes</g3> checkbox.
To show or hide navigation light shaft bounding volumes, in the <g1>scene editor toolbar</g1>, open the <g2>gizmo options</g2> menu and use the <g3>Light shaft bounding volumes</g3> checkbox.
The <g1>LightShaftComponent</g1> settings have been simplified and now have settings to control quality and performance.
The <g1>LightShaftComponent</g1> settings have been simplified and now have settings to control quality and performance.
Xenko now supports streaming for textures.
Xenko now supports streaming for textures.
This significantly decreases the time it takes to load a game or scene, uses less memory, and makes your game easier to scale.
This significantly decreases the time it takes to load a game or scene, uses less memory, and makes your game easier to scale.
Streaming is enabled for textures by default.
Streaming is enabled for textures by default.
You can find the option in the texture properties under <g1>Format</g1>.
You can find the option in the texture properties under <g1>Format</g1>.
You can also set the global <g1>Streaming</g1> settings in <g2>Game settings</g2>.
You can also set the global <g1>Streaming</g1> settings in <g2>Game settings</g2>.
You can now set which render groups a camera renders under <g1>Graphics Compositor > Entry points > Render masks</g1>.
You can now set which render groups a camera renders under <g1>Graphics Compositor > Entry points > Render masks</g1>.
For example, you can have a model be visible to Camera A but invisible to Camera B.
For example, you can have a model be visible to Camera A but invisible to Camera B.
For details, see <g1>Render groups and masks</g1>.
For details, see <g1>Render groups and masks</g1>.
The <g1>Game Profiler</g1> script now displays more information and is easier to use.
The <g1>Game Profiler</g1> script now displays more information and is easier to use.
switch between CPU, GPU, and FPS-only results with <g1>F1</g1>
switch between CPU, GPU, and FPS-only results with <g1>F1</g1>
sort the result pages by <g1>Name</g1> or <g2>Time</g2> with <g3>F2</g3>
sort the result pages by <g1>Name</g1> or <g2>Time</g2> with <g3>F2</g3>
change how frequently the profiler gets and displays new results with <g1>- / +</g1>
change how frequently the profiler gets and displays new results with <g1>- / +</g1>
jump to a results page with the <g1>number keys</g1>, or move forward and backwards with <g2>F3</g2> and <g3>F4</g3>
jump to a results page with the <g1>number keys</g1>, or move forward and backwards with <g2>F3</g2> and <g3>F4</g3>
You can now display debug text at runtime.
You can now display debug text at runtime.
The input system has been rewritten to track different input devices and allow for better extensibility.
The input system has been rewritten to track different input devices and allow for better extensibility.
Allows detection of added/removed devices through events on the InputManager
Allows detection of added/removed devices through events on the InputManager
High-level <g1>IGamePadDevice</g1> replaces the gamepad functionality, with support for XInput
High-level <g1>IGamePadDevice</g1> replaces the gamepad functionality, with support for XInput
Lower-level <g1>IGameControllerDevice</g1> allows access to numbered buttons/axes
Lower-level <g1>IGameControllerDevice</g1> allows access to numbered buttons/axes
Support for different keyboard layouts and IME for text input
Support for different keyboard layouts and IME for text input
Access to resolution and absolute coordinates for mouse/pointer devices
Access to resolution and absolute coordinates for mouse/pointer devices
<g1>KeyEvent</g1> now has a <g2>RepeatCount</g2> member, indicating how many times the key has been repeated while being held down
<g1>KeyEvent</g1> now has a <g2>RepeatCount</g2> member, indicating how many times the key has been repeated while being held down
To support graphics functionalities on every platform, we've implemented missing features for the DirectX 12 rendering backend:
To support graphics functionalities on every platform, we've implemented missing features for the DirectX 12 rendering backend:
unordered access views for textures and buffers
unordered access views for textures and buffers
For more details, see the <g1>Changelog</g1> below.
For more details, see the <g1>Changelog</g1> below.
Fresnel describes how light is reflected depending on the angle the material is viewed from.
Fresnel describes how light is reflected depending on the angle the material is viewed from.
Typically, high angles are more reflective.
Typically, high angles are more reflective.
Previously, Xenko used an imprecise polynomial approximation to compute the fresnel for environment lighting (such as cubemaps), resulting in a bigger-than-expected white outline.
Previously, Xenko used an imprecise polynomial approximation to compute the fresnel for environment lighting (such as cubemaps), resulting in a bigger-than-expected white outline.
Xenko now defaults to a precomputed BRDF environment lookup texture that matches our default lighting equations (GGX Schlick).
Xenko now defaults to a precomputed BRDF environment lookup texture that matches our default lighting equations (GGX Schlick).
This produces much more accurate rendering.
This produces much more accurate rendering.
The documentation is now available in Japanese.
The documentation is now available in Japanese.
To switch languages, use the <g1>Language</g1> button in the top-right of the documentation site.
To switch languages, use the <g1>Language</g1> button in the top-right of the documentation site.
Changed checking support for sensors using <g1>Sensor.IsSupported</g1> to <g2>InputManager.Sensor != null</g2> (where <g3>Sensor</g3> is the name of the sensor you're checking)
Changed checking support for sensors using <g1>Sensor.IsSupported</g1> to <g2>InputManager.Sensor != null</g2> (where <g3>Sensor</g3> is the name of the sensor you're checking)
The <g1>HasDown/Pressed/ReleasedMouseButtons()</g1> functions on the <g2>InputManager</g2> are now properties
The <g1>HasDown/Pressed/ReleasedMouseButtons()</g1> functions on the <g2>InputManager</g2> are now properties
Removed <g1>GetGamePad()</g1>; use <g2>IGamePadDevice.State</g2> to acquire a gamepad state
Removed <g1>GetGamePad()</g1>; use <g2>IGamePadDevice.State</g2> to acquire a gamepad state
To obtain a gamepad, use <g1>InputManager.GamePads</g1>, <g2>InputManager.GetGamePadByIndex(index)</g2> or use the <g3>InputManager.DeviceAdded/Removed</g3> events
To obtain a gamepad, use <g1>InputManager.GamePads</g1>, <g2>InputManager.GetGamePadByIndex(index)</g2> or use the <g3>InputManager.DeviceAdded/Removed</g3> events
Removed <g1>GamePadState.IsConnected</g1>; use the <g2>InputManager.DeviceAdded/Removed</g2> events or check the value returned by <g3>InputManager.GetGamePadByIndex(index) != null</g3>
Removed <g1>GamePadState.IsConnected</g1>; use the <g2>InputManager.DeviceAdded/Removed</g2> events or check the value returned by <g3>InputManager.GetGamePadByIndex(index) != null</g3>
Locking the mouse with <g1>InputManager.LockMousePosition()</g1> no longer automatically hides the cursor; use <g2>IGame.IsMouseVisible</g2> for this
Locking the mouse with <g1>InputManager.LockMousePosition()</g1> no longer automatically hides the cursor; use <g2>IGame.IsMouseVisible</g2> for this
Removed <g1>PointerEvent.PointerType</g1>; use <g2>PointerEvent.Device is IMouseDevice</g2> to check if the event came from a mouse
Removed <g1>PointerEvent.PointerType</g1>; use <g2>PointerEvent.Device is IMouseDevice</g2> to check if the event came from a mouse
Renamed <g1>State</g1> on <g2>PointerEvent</g2> to <g3>EventType</g3> and its type to <g4>PointerEventType</g4>
Renamed <g1>State</g1> on <g2>PointerEvent</g2> to <g3>EventType</g3> and its type to <g4>PointerEventType</g4>
Removed <g1>KeyEvent.Type</g1>; to check if this was a pressed or released event, use the boolean <g2>KeyEvent.IsDown</g2>
Removed <g1>KeyEvent.Type</g1>; to check if this was a pressed or released event, use the boolean <g2>KeyEvent.IsDown</g2>
<g1>MouseWheelDelta</g1> is now <g2>-1</g2> or <g3>1</g3> per scroll unit instead of <g4>-120</g4> or <g5>120</g5>
<g1>MouseWheelDelta</g1> is now <g2>-1</g2> or <g3>1</g3> per scroll unit instead of <g4>-120</g4> or <g5>120</g5>
Removed <g1>MultiTouchEnabled</g1> on the <g2>InputManager</g2>; multi-touch is always enabled
Removed <g1>MultiTouchEnabled</g1> on the <g2>InputManager</g2>; multi-touch is always enabled
Removed <g1>ExtinctionFactor</g1> and <g2>ExtinctionRatio</g2> to simplify the light shaft component
Removed <g1>ExtinctionFactor</g1> and <g2>ExtinctionRatio</g2> to simplify the light shaft component
Now default <g1>RenderStageSelector</g1> select all entity groups
Now default <g1>RenderStageSelector</g1> select all entity groups
On Linux, when switching the underlying graphics platform, rendering doesn't occur or fail.
On Linux, when switching the underlying graphics platform, rendering doesn't occur or fail.
